rule:
No social media, porn, or unnecessary phone
 use before completing your first 2 hours of deep work.

Work in 45–60 minute deep-focus blocks, 
followed by 10-minute physical breaks.
Focus on one task at a time — no multitasking.
Reward yourself after completing work, not before.

Exercise daily — bodyweight, running,
 or home workout to naturally boost dopamine.

Sleep 7–8 hours every night;
 avoid screens 30 minutes before bed.

Drink 2–3 liters of water per day — 
 dehydration lowers focus and dopamine.

Avoid junk food and sugary drinks; 
fuel your brain for sustained motivation.

Limit music while studying; use it
 only for workouts or relaxation.
Phone stays on silent and out of reach during focus sessions.

No porn, edging, or sexual content online
 — train dopamine to reward discipline.

If bored, do pushups, walk, or code — don’t
 chase easy dopamine from scrolling.

Respect yourself — don’t chase
 attention from girls online or offline.

Focus on self-improvement first;
 social life and relationships come after.

Avoid instant dopamine interactions
 like flirting or likes; patience trains your brain.

Observe boundaries! 
— real-life friendships matter more than online crushes.

Spend 15 minutes daily learning something useful
 (Python, civil engineering, skills).

Read one insightful article or book page daily
 to train attention span.

Write down 3 things you are grateful for every day
 — this boosts baseline dopamine naturally

Keep your room and environment clean
 — a cluttered space clutters your brain.

Keep your room and environment clean
 — a cluttered space clutters your brain.

Plan tomorrow tonight
 — a clear plan reduces mental fatigue.

Avoid comparing yourself with others online
 — lowers motivation and dopamine.

Accept boredom — your brain needs to reset
 to enjoy slow rewards.

Take responsibility for your actions
 — self-accountability strengthens mental dopamine pathways.

When tempted by distractions, ask:
 “Will this help me tomorrow?”

Avoid instant gratification — 
train your patience and long-term reward circuits.

If negative thoughts arise,
 replace them with a productive action immediately.

Avoid gossip, negativity, and toxic people
 — they hijack your focus and dopamine.

Track your daily wins —
 even small achievements spike healthy dopamine.

Take a 5–10 minute walk every 2–3 hours
 — increases focus and dopamine naturally.

Use dopamine rewards strategically: 
music/workouts after work, not before.

Hard work itself is the reward — 
 train your brain to enjoy effort.

Limit unnecessary chatting online
 — focus energy on skill-building and personal growth.

Use the “2-minute rule”: if a task takes <2 mins
, do it immediately — avoids procrastination buildup.

Every night, review what you did right and wrong —
 reflection strengthens your brain’s reward-for-effort system.

Cold exposure (showers or brief walks outside in cold)
 increases dopamine and resilience.

Learn to tolerate discomfort —
 skip easy dopamine snacks to train mental toughness.

Avoid “just browsing” online —
 always have an intentional goal before using devices.

Break your tasks into micro-goals — 
 each small win releases dopamine.

Break your tasks into micro-goals —
  each small win releases dopamine.

No excessive online debates or arguments — 
  they hijack attention and produce fake dopamine hits.

Practice delayed gratification exercises: 
wait before eating snacks, opening social apps, or watching videos.

Pair learning with physical movement occasionally
 — walking while learning boosts dopamine and memory.

Avoid negative self-talk — 
it decreases dopamine and motivation.

Keep a “distraction log”: every time you drift,
 write it down — awareness retrains the brain.

Occasionally do “dopamine fasting” —
 3–6 hours without social media, music, games, or snacks.

Visualize your goals for 5 mins daily
 — anticipation triggers healthy dopamine spikes.

Use small wins to start your day —
 success early triggers motivation.

Practice deep breathing (4-7-8 method) 
 to stabilize dopamine and reduce stress.
Spend time outdoors daily — sunlight boosts dopamine naturally

Avoid watching TV or random videos
 for long periods — it desensitizes the brain.

Use a “focus playlist” with low-dopamine music
 during work to enhance attention.

Every Sunday, plan your week — prioritization increases
 motivation and reduces wasted energy.

Occasionally try new, challenging activities
 (learning a new skill, sport, or coding trick) — novelty spikes dopamine in healthy ways.

Practice self-imposed limitations 
(no phone for meals, no sugar on weekdays) — strengthens discipline circuits.

Avoid relying on motivation — rely on system and rules,
 so dopamine is naturally earned.

Use accountability partners sparingly — 
 external reinforcement spikes dopamine, but don’t overdepend.

Reflect weekly on what distracted you and
 adjust rules — fine-tune your dopamine ecosystem.
Never Give Up. Believe It .

Dont reveal your progress,goals and yourself  
 to your friends and family . If sharing 
 anything makes things more updated anf far then 
 just do it but with caution.
Even your own brothers are not trustworthy.

Dont be shy or feel nervous of what yiu meseed up. \n Dont feel bad.\n Once you complete your 2 yrs journey, it will be absolute fine.
